Explanations about Options.-S(M):
When creating a new session, this option can be used to specify a meaningful name for
 the session. This name identifies the session for "screen -list" and "screen -r"
 actions. It substitutes the default [tty.host] suffix.
Explanations about Options.-r(M):
resumes a detached screen session. No other options (except combinations with -d/-D)
 may be specified, though an optional prefix of [pid.]tty.host may be needed to
 distinguish between multiple detached screen sessions. The second form is used to
 connect to another user's screen session which runs in multiuser mode. This indicates
 that screen should look for sessions in another user's directory. This requires
 setuid-root.
Explanations about Options.-wipe(M):
does the same as "screen -ls", but removes destroyed sessions instead of marking them
 as `dead'. An unreachable session is considered dead, when its name matches either
 the name of the local host, or the explicitly given parameter, if any. See the -r
 flag for a description how to construct matches.

Answers.MP Summary: screen manager with VT100/ANSI terminal emulation
Top-3 Scripts:
su_485884: #!/bin/bash
#This is the process you want to suspend.
screen -mdS child bash -c "cat /dev/urandom | base64"
#This is the process ID of the child process
THEPID=$(screen -list | grep child | cut -f1 -d'.' | sed 's/\W//g')
#Send SIGSTOP to the child process.
kill -SIGSTOP ${THEPID}
#Now it is suspended. This process will sleep for 10 seconds asynchronously, then resume the process.
screen -mdS monitor bash -c "sleep 10; kill -SIGCONT ${THEPID}"

screen -rS child

Explanations about Options.-f(M):
Force immediate halt, power-off, or reboot. When specified once, this results in an
 immediate but clean shutdown by the system manager. When specified twice, this results
 in an immediate shutdown without contacting the system manager. See the description of
 --force in systemctl(1) for more details.

Explanations about Options.--addmode(M):
output name
 Add a mode to the set of valid modes for an output.
Explanations about Options.--brightness(M):
Multiply the gamma values on the crtc currently attached to the output to specified
 floating value. Useful for overly bright or overly dim outputs. However, this is a
 software only modification, if your hardware has support to actually change the
 brightness, you will probably prefer to use xbacklight.
Explanations about Options.--output(M): Selects an output to reconfigure. Use either the name of the output or the XID.
Explanations about Options.--query(M):
When this option is present, or when no configuration changes are requested, xrandr
 will display the current state of the system.

Explanations about Options.-d(M):
Highlight the differences between successive updates. Option will read optional
 argument that changes highlight to be permanent, allowing to see what has changed
 at least once since first iteration.
